docs.lead_paragraph: John Allison, chairman of BB&T, leads his company with an Ayn Randian “commitment to reason.” To him, the government’s rush to try to fix the economy is a nightmare come true.

headline.main: Why We Must Ration Health Care
headline.print_headline: Why We Must Ration Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO weeks ago, we wrote about the computer program DriveSharp, intended to help older people drive more safely. The article drew comments about whether aging drivers should be tested before having their licenses renewed. ''Unleashing an aging baby boomer generation on the roadways will cause a genuine public health crisis in the years to come,'' one reader wrote. It's a valid concern because a greater number of older people are on the road and they are driving more miles than before, according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. And the number of older drivers is expected to increase in the next 15 to 20 years, when one in four drivers will be 65 or older.
docs.abstract: Automobiles section blog entry on testing older drivers and whether they are hazard on roads (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, Room for Debate ran a discussion about the annoyances of air travel. We received more than 600 comments with readers' grievances and their ideas for improving everything from seat space to airport services. Below are excerpts of some of their suggestions.

headline.main: Check-In to Bag Claim: Better Ways to Fly

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama heads off for a 24-hour escape to Camp David this morning, but not before giving his administration a pat on the back for dealing with the recession. In his weekly address he said the stimulus package was responsible for improved economic figures released on Friday. He noted that the report also showed the country will continue to lose jobs.
docs.abstract: Economic news and health care dominate the news at the end of the week.
docs.snippet: Economic news and health care dominate the news at the end of the week.
